**Name:** Travel time

**Source:** [Weiss et al. (2018), Weiss et al. (2020), Ryan et al. (2025)](https://doi.org/10.1038/nature25181, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-020-1059-1, https://idem-lab.github.io/traveltime/)

**Version:** software: 0.0.0.9000

**Keywords:** travel time, accessibility, cities

**Type:** Raster

**Description:** Travel time to nearest urban centre: Weiss et al. (2018) https://doi.org/10.1038/nature25181

Travel time to nearest health facility: Weiss et al. (2020)https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-020-1059-1

Travel time to â€¦ anywhere. The R package [`traveltime`](https://idem-lab.github.io/traveltime/) enables a user to create a map of travel time over an area of interest from a user-specified set of geographic coordinates and friction surface. The package provides convenient access to global friction surfaces for walking and motorised travel for the year 2020. The final result is a raster of the area of interest where the value in each cell is the lowest travel time in minutes to any of the specified locations.

**Units:** minutes

**Available in geocoded GMD?** Yes

**Available from Space2Stats?** Yes

<small>
**Usage:** The R package implements methods from Weiss et al. 2018, 2020 to calculate travel time from given locations over a friction surface. Pre-prepared walking or motorised friction surfaces can be obtained with `get_friction_surface`. User can also provide their own friction surface. This surface but must be in resistance units (1/conductance), e.g. minutes/meter. See Van Etten 2017.

**Limitations:** Over large areas this function can require significant RAM and will be slow.

**Examples:** NA

**Access:** Direct download travel time rasters from Malaria Atlas Project.R package: https://idem-lab.github.io/traveltime/
</small>
